f'(x) ≈ [f(x+h) - f(x)] / h

Accuracy: O(h) - first order
Uses: current point and one ahead

f'(x) ≈ [f(x+h) - f(x-h)] / 2h

Accuracy: O(h²) - second order
Better than forward/backward!

f''(x) ≈ [f(x+h) - 2f(x) + f(x-h)] / h²

Accuracy: O(h²)
Stencil coefficients: +1, -2, +1

For dy/dt = f(t,y):

y_{n+1} = y_n + h × f(t_n, y_n)

Uses current slope to step forward.
First-order accurate, error O(h²) per step.

To avoid aliasing:

fs ≥ 2 × fmax

Sample at least twice the highest frequency.
This IS discretization of continuous signals!

When high frequencies appear as low frequencies due to insufficient sampling rate.

Example: Wagon wheels appearing to spin backward in movies.

Prevention: Sample faster OR use anti-aliasing filter.

For dy/dt = λy (λ < 0):

h < 2/|λ|

If step too large → solution oscillates and diverges.

Smaller h (finer grid):
✓ More accurate
✗ More computation
✗ More round-off error accumulation

Larger h (coarser grid):
✓ Faster
✗ Less accurate

cards.front: Why is central difference better than forward?
cards.back:
Central: errors from both sides partially CANCEL
→ O(h²) accuracy

Forward: one-sided, no cancellation
→ O(h) accuracy

Halving h: Central improves 4×, Forward only 2×

1. Forward/Backward Euler: O(h)
2. Trapezoidal: O(h²)
3. Runge-Kutta 4 (RK4): O(h⁴)

Higher order = fewer steps for same accuracy

cards.front: What is a stencil in finite differences?
cards.back:
The pattern of neighboring points used in a finite difference formula.

Example for f''(x):
[+1] [-2] [+1]  ←  stencil
 x-h   x   x+h

Divide by h²

• Time discretization (finite differences)
• Adaptive step size (smaller h when voltage changes fast)
• Newton-Raphson at each time step

Tradeoff: accuracy vs. simulation time
